Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-SEED: Solar Optics-based Active Pasteurization (SOAP) for Greywater Reuse and Integrated Thermal (GRIT) Building Control
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this EFRI-SEED project is to produce transformative science with unforeseen opportunities for the design of next-generation sustainable building technologies, as well as, of micro optics and fluids networks innovation. SOAP GRIT Building Control will constitute the first building system for greywater disinfection coupled with thermal storage and energy management from solar energy. The researchers aim to establish new technologies for selection of light and heat flow transmission/conduction based on microoptics that can supplant current research developments that deploy thicker, heavier and often pricey mechanical lens systems. By integrating advances in biologically-inspired photonics and optofluidics technologies from bioengineering for light control and waste processing at microscale into buildings systems, new thresholds of water and energy expenditure reduction and management can be accomplished. Likewise, the knowledge obtained from SOAP GRIT Building Control will provide the civil and bioengineering community with valuable performance criteria of micro-optics based technology for integrating thermal control and disinfection derived from solar energy.

The interdisciplinary nature of this research will contribute to widen the scope of beneficiaries while demonstrating that new interdisciplinary collaborations for sustainable architecture models can accelerate the development of energy efficient building technologies through unconsidered scales of action. The successful completion of this research will stimulate a number of studies of energy efficient integrated building systems nation-wide. This research will contribute to develop courses for the new minor in biomimicry/sustainable architecture at UC Berkeley's architecture undergraduate program. The topic of next-generation sustainable architecture is attractive to younger students and underrepresented minorities, including K12, which will be involved in this proposal through a summer program in collaboration with architect Tom McKeag, director of BioDreamMachine, a California non-profit educational institution dedicated to bringing the benefits of bio-inspired design to K12 public education.

The FY 2010 EFRI-SEED Topic that supports this project was sponsored by the US National Science Foundation (NSF) Directorates for Engineering (ENG), Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE), and Computer & Information Science and Engineering in collaboration with the US Department of Energy (DOE) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar Optics-based Active Panels (SOAP) for Greywater Reuse and Integrated Thermal (GRIT) Building Control research establishes an integrated greywater and thermal building control system activated by solar energy. The building system is designed for regions of acute water scarcity with heating requirements due to daily swings that span a wide geographical range.  Sunlight is used to capture and store energy as a means to disinfect greywater providing an integrated method to balance water demands, and day and night thermal shifts in high-density buildings particularly located in hot/arid and temperate dry winter/tropical savannahs regions. SOAP for GRIT research involves the pioneering integration of an integrated microarray optical detection system placed on a polymeric substrate (exterior building thin panel). The research has investigated the combination of microlenses, and photocatalytic suspended nanoparticles target a comprehensive greywater (recycled) disinfection in building facades- a system we have termed “Packed Optical Reactive Elements” (PORE). In parallel, this investigation has also explored alternative morphologies of the reactor concepts in the form of louvers –“Vertically Integrated Multistep” (VIMs), and “Cylindrical Optical Reactive Elements” (CORE). 

As any real water matrix, greywater is highly heterogeneous. Consequently, developing a reliable treatment process for such a matrix, especially under variable reaction conditions (owing to variable sunlight and other factors) requires a careful diagnosis. Through our research, we have studied the optical characteristics of the greywater matrix with the ultimate goal of developing a synthetic greywater that models real greywater matrices both optically and chemically. This synthetic matrix has been used as a feedstock and matrix for realistic photocatalytic reactor characterization. 

Through numerical calculations, we have determined In the PORE system that 100% greywater disinfection can be accomplished for different types of bacteria including Escherichia coli. The light focusing accomplished by the microlens enables the solar collector efficiency is enhanced from 25% to 65%, compared to an equal system without the microlens. Current experiments are presenting that we can accomplish 100 times increased E. coli disinfection efficiency in the microlens panels when compared to a conventional TiO2 flat film panel. 

The VIMS (Vertically Integrated Multi-Step) panel consists of titanium dioxide coated plates forming louvers along which greywater cascades sequentially, driven by gravity, each fixed at an optimal angle. Two key mechanisms drive the functions of the system. In solar thermal heating, greywater absorbs sunlight and the temperature increases. In solar photocatalysis, sunlight penetrates greywater and strikes the TiO2. The resultant hydroxyl radicals generated oxidize water pollutants and microorganisms, inactivating them through the sequential attack.

Our results indicate that higher thermal efficiencies, as described by ASHRAE characterization of solar thermal collectors, correspond to higher photocatalytic treatment efficiency, across two photocatalytic reactor designs (VIMS, and a bulk chamber reactor using ALCOA EcoClean Titanium Dioxide-Coated Aluminum siding). While these results proved our concept, they were insufficient to demonstrate a real, working system – thermal efficiencies and reaction rates were simply too low to be relevant for an impactful application. The research team is currently exploring relationships between inactivation and operating parameters – primarily, angle and flow rate – under real sunlight conditions in a west-facing vertical configuration in Berkeley, CA. 

Numerical calculations, characterization, design, and prototyping have been implemented to evaluate the integration of SOAP panel in new buildings, as well as retrofitting regarding the structural impact and mechanical systems. An evaluation of cost-benefit and impact at the local, regional and the global scale has been carried for sites under water scarcity in the US and globally. The investigation also evaluates potential failure mechanisms (optical, optofluidic interface, thermal, structural and biological) of an exterior wall system and proposed remediation for variable urban densities. SOAP for GRIT targets resourcing by addressing the interdependencies between water, energy, and waste researched and designed from the nano to the building and urban scale. A cohesive convergence of architecture, engineering, and science has proven essential to render this investigation possible.
